content: this is a fantasy story about a bastard son of a duke named eathel

Once, in the land of Eldoria, ruled by dukes and duchesses, there lived a young lad named Eathel. Eathel was no ordinary citizen—he was the unacknowledged, bastard son of Duke Eldon, a man known for his strength, agility, and strategic skills. Eathel, on the other hand, was recognized only by his mother, the lovely wooden-carving enchantress named Seraphine.

Eathel, unlike his noble father, lived a humble life. His hair was as dark and messy as a raven's nest, his eyes sparkled with the mysterious turquoise hue of distant oceans, and he had an unmatchable, unruly spirit. Little did he know that he was more than just a bastard boy named for his mother's favorite stone—his destiny was to shape the future of Eldoria.

The rage of war was kindling amongst the four provinces, and the land was quivering, awaiting the forthcoming disaster. Duke Eldon, trying to maintain peace and fight the war simultaneously, was on the brink of despair. Meanwhile, Eathel remained blissfully unaware of these societal tensions, basking in his modest life with Seraphine and carving beautiful woods with enchanting details.

Driven by curiosity and a yearning for adventure, Eathel departed from his home and wandered deep into the Eldorian woods one day. He stumbled across a stone tablet with ancient inscriptions and an intricate carving of a dragon and a prince locked in an eternal battle.

The words inscribed onto the stone tablet echoed in his mind, forming an age-old prophecy:

'The blood of Eldon, pure yet stained,
In a young heart, adventure ingrained.
With dragon's flame and warrior's might,
Will bring forth Eldoria's light.'

As the words sunk in, Eathel was struck with frosty realization. The prophecy spoke of him—he was the blood of Eldon, denounced yet pure, and the future of Eldoria was entwined with his fate. He could no longer remain an oblivious woodcarver—he was the secret weapon Eldoria needed for its survival.

Emboldened by this newfound duty, Eathel embarked on an epic journey to harness the warrior within him, conquer the flame-breathing dragon mentioned in the prophecy, and bring peace to Eldoria.

Eathel journeyed through ferocious landscapes and fought monstrous creatures, growing stronger every day. Through mysterious encounters and secretive incantation lessons from magical beings, he tamed a draconic beast as an ally—a feat impossible for mere warriors.

News of this powerful, mysterious young warrior spread across Eldoria and soon reached Duke Eldon. The Duke was dumbfounded to learn of the existence of a bastard son and was filled with regret for the estrangement.

Eventually, Eathel led an army of Eldorian warriors and his mighty dragon into battle, tearing apart enemy lines with fiery wrath and unfaltering bravery. He didn't just emerge victorious from the war, he defeated tyranny and scripted Eldoria's golden epoch.

After the war, standing amidst the cheering crowd in the grand Eldorian castle, Eathel found himself facing his father, Duke Eldon. The Duke officially acknowledged Eathel, not just as his son, but as his rightful heir, the future Duke of Eldoria—the land he saved, the land he loved.

This fantasy tale, therefore, not only tells of Eathel's courage and strength but reminds us that one's destiny is not determined by birth, but by deeds. It is a tale of profound courage, unshakeable tenacity, and the relentless pursuit to forge one's own fate.

Title: The Bastard of Graystone

In the kingdom of Aldoria, Eathel was known in the shadows, never in the spotlight. Though he was born of noble blood, his birth was cloaked with disgrace. He was the bastard son of Duke Griffith of Graystone, a man renowned for his power and influence. But Eathel was his secret thorn, a constant reminder of an indecorous liaison with a beautiful servant named Liliana.

Growing up in the alcoves of Graystone Manor, Eathel was never accepted as one of the nobles. He was never given the title of a prince, but was instead relegated to serve as a scribe for the duke. He wore not the armor of knights but the robes of a commoner. His dreams were set aside, his potential ignored. But beneath this facade of humility, there was an ember of rebellion that burnt furiously in Eathel's heart. 

One day, Eathel unearthed a dark secret. Duke Griffith, his father, had made a pact with the Faërie Queen. In exchange for his increased power over the other domains, he'd agreed to give the Faërie Queen all the first-born children of Aldoria. He'd been doing it for years, and it was to be Eathel’s half-brother, Rowan's turn next. 

Eathel faced a fierce moral dilemma. Should he save his half-brother, whom he was always overshadowed by, and expose his father’s dishonor? Was he willing to confront the Faërie Queen and risk the wrath of her ethereal forces? Eathel decided he could not let another innocent be lost in this wicked bargain. If he was to die, he'd die with honor and valor, something the duke knew little about.

With a hidden lore book he had stumbled upon in the Duke's library, he learned sorcery and swordsmanship. His status as a scribe came in handy and he began to devise plans, gather allies from the commoners, serfs and the kingdom's guard unsatisfied with the Duke's rule. 

Eathel ventured into the Faërie realm, facing doom-spelled heaths and enchanted forests. He confronted wyverns and vanquished pixie tricksters. Along his journey, he found kinship among the discarded first-borns, exiled and enslaved in the Faërie Queen's domain.

The culmination came when Eathel faced the Faërie Queen. He exposed Duke Griffith's treachery to the people of Aldoria by using a magical mirror to broadcast their duel. He battled courageously and revealed his identity as the bastard son, defying not only the queen but his father's oppressive rule. Finally, he defeated the queen by binding her with a spell of obedience contained in the lore book. 

Eathel was hailed as a hero. He declined to take over as the Duke after his father was banished, preferring to free his subjects from the yoke of inherited power. Instead, he implemented a new governance structure, making Aldoria a haven where power lay in the hands of its people. 

As for Eathel, he continued his journey, exploring distant lands and uncharted territories. He had come into the world scorned, but he left it admired and respected; a bastard son who became a legend in his own right. His tale serves to remind everyone that nobility is not defined by birth, but by one's deeds and heart.

his father's duchy is called tera. if we're basing tera in western europe circa 1100-1200, what assurances would eathel have that he'd inherit tera?

In a historical context such as western Europe during 1100-1200, being a bastard son would typically pose several obstacles for Eathel if he sought to inherit his father's duchy, Tera.

However, there are circumstances in which Eathel could actually rise to such a position:

1. Legitimization: If for any reason there is no legitimate heir or the legitimate heirs are deemed unfit to rule, the Duke could legitimize Eathel, formally recognizing him as his legal offspring. This practice was not unheard of during the period.

2. Acknowledgement: Duke, acknowledging Eathel as his son even without legitimization, might have enough influence within the court and over his vassals to ensure a smooth inheritance transition.

3. Heroic Deeds: If Eathel distinguishes himself in some grand way (say, by achieving great military victory or by performing some act of undeniable importance and benefit to the duchy), he may build a strong reputation and popular support that could assist him in claiming inheritance.

4. Law of the Land: The rules of inheritance varied widely in different regions during this period. In some regions, "bastard feudalism" was common, with vassals holding land in return for service, like military service. If Tera operated under such a system, Eathel's military prowess could play a significant role in his claim for his father's duchy.

That being said, these are potential scenarios and exceptions rather than the rule, and each would have its own challenges. The key to any of these avenues would be the Duke's public acknowledgment and acceptance of Eathel as his son, giving Eathel the social standing necessary to make any claim at all.
tell me more about real bastards who inherited their father's/mother's title(s) not william the conqueror

Absolutely! There are indeed historical instances of illegitimate children inheriting their parents' titles, even outside of the famous example of William the Conqueror.

1. Henry Fitzroy: He was the illegitimate son of King Henry VIII of England. Henry VIII had him legitimized and gave him Dukedoms of Richmond and of Somerset. Although he never inherited the throne, the fact that Henry had no other sons at the time led to speculation that Fitzroy might have been his father's heir.

2. Robert of Gloucester: Robert was an illegitimate son of King Henry I of England and played a pivotal role in the war between Henry's daughter Matilda and King Stephen during The Anarchy, a war of succession in the mid-12th century England.

3. John of Gaunt: While not technically an illegitimate child himself, John of Gaunt had four children with his long-term mistress Katherine Swynford. These children, known as the Beauforts, were later legitimized by an Act of Parliament, and their descendants included King Henry VII and, by extension, the entire Tudor dynasty.

4. Alfonso XI of Castile: Alfonso already had a male heir when he illegitimately fathered Henry (later Henry II of Castile). However, after Alfonso's death, Henry first was given titular command of a part of his father's realm by his half-brother, and later led a rebellion against his brother to become king himself.

These examples make it clear that while illegitimate children were at a disadvantage when it came to succession in the Medieval Era, it was not impossible for them to rise to power in the right circumstances.

Pippin the Hunchback was the son of Charlemagne, the first emperor of the Holy Roman Empire. As the eldest and illegitimate son of Charlemagne, Pippin was initially viewed as a possible heir. However, later political manipulations led to his half-brothers, Charlemagne's sons from his later marriages, becoming the preferred heirs. Pippin eventually participated in a revolt against his father, which resulted in his being disinherited. But he still stands as an example of an illegitimate son who, for a time, was considered for inheritance of his father's titles.

You might be referring to King Henry II of England, who reigned from 1154 to 1189. He's often considered one of the most effective of England's monarchs. Henry II established the basis for the English Common Law system and expanded his empire to include other territories, stretching from the northern edge of the British Isles to the Pyrenees. These moves significantly increased royal power, which set the foundation for the institution of monarchical rule that was carried through the centuries. Plus, his children included Richard the Lionheart and King John, equally famous in their own rights.
tell me more about henry ii's early life

Henry II was born in Le Mans, France in 1133. He was the eldest son of Geoffrey Plantagenet, Count of Anjou, and Matilda, the daughter of the English King Henry I. His father was a noble in the province of Anjou in France, and Geoffrey gave him the nickname "Plantagenet" due to his hobby of hunting and habit of wearing a sprig of planta genista in his helmet.

Henry spent much of his early life in Anjou, learning about the intricacies of feudal politics and war. His mother was heavily involved in a long civil war against her cousin Stephen of Blois who had seized the English throne after the death of her father, Henry I. This dispute postponed Matilda’s son's ascendancy to the throne.

However, the young Henry was energetic and ambitious. By the age of 14, with the help of Louis VII of France, he began his own campaigns in England. His determination finally paid off when, at just twenty-one years old, he reached a compromise to be Stephen’s successor. Stephen recognized Henry as his heir in 1153, and when Stephen died the next year, Henry ascended to the throne. This signified the end of the unstable period known as 'The Anarchy' and marked the beginning of Henry II's reign. Henry was crowned King of England on December 19, 1154, and his wife Eleanor of Aquitaine was crowned queen. Together, they had five sons and three daughters.
what things happened to him in anjou?

In Anjou, a region in western France, the young Henry Plantagenet, later known as Henry II of England was brought up and educated under the watchful eye of his father, Geoffrey Plantagenet, Count of Anjou. Geoffrey was a very smart and shrewd ruler, and he provided his son with an excellent education in governance and military tactics, priming him for his future role.

In 1144, when Henry was just a boy, his father successfully claimed the title of Duke of Normandy from his enemy Stephen of England. This was an important event during Henry's upbringing in Anjou as it marked a significant expansion of Angevin influence and territory.

After his father's death in 1151, the 18-year-old Henry inherited the titles of Count of Anjou, Duke of Normandy, and also of Maine. This not only added to his growing power and influence but also laid the foundation for the vast Angevin Empire that would later come into existence under his rule. These titles also solidified his strength and position in his later fight for the English throne.

The years Henry spent in Anjou were formative, shaping him into an effective military leader and administrator, and setting the stage for his future accomplishments as the King of England.
what are two important childhood experiences that don't have to do w/ politics

Despite our extensive knowledge of his political life, there is unfortunately little detailed information about Henry II's childhood experiences outside of a political context. Additionally, the nature of his upbringing - as the son of Geoffrey Plantagenet and Matilda, and as a future ruler - meant that much of his early life was inherently political. However, here are two general aspects of his early life that give some insight:

1. Education: It is likely that Henry II, like most noble children of the era, received a comprehensive education. He was probably taught reading, writing, arithmetic, and Latin - as well as history, music, and the arts. He also might have learned about religious studies, as religion played a crucial role in Medieval society. Several historical sources describe Henry as intelligent and well-read, suggesting the robustness of his education.

2. Knight Training: Another crucial element of Henry's childhood would have been martial training. Knights were the military elites of their day, so Henry, a future ruler, was almost certainly trained in horsemanship, strategy, and weaponry from a young age. This training instilled in him the martial skills, discipline, and bravery that later won him acclaim as a warrior and leader.
are there any other formative experiences from nobles around the same time and their childhoods?

Yes, several historical accounts of notable nobles from the same era give us some insight into their formative experiences during their childhoods. Here are two examples:

1. Richard (future Richard the Lionheart): Richard I of England, who was one of Henry II's sons, reportedly spent much of his childhood in his mother's duchy of Aquitaine (present-day southwestern France). He was said to be very close to his mother, Eleanor of Aquitaine. From her, he developed a deep love of poetry and music. This is notably non-political and was crucial in the shaping of Richard's character.

2. Louis VII of France: Louis was educated at the abbey of Saint-Denis, one of the most important French monasteries of the time. Even though his father wanted him to be a soldier, Louis showed a much stronger inclination towards religious matters. His early emphasis on religion greatly influenced his later life. He became known as Louis "the Monk" and his reign was characterized by his piety and emphasis on religious, rather than secular, matters.
what nobles around this time were infamously uninterested in religion

While it's challenging to identify nobles from the Middle Ages who were overtly uninterested in religion, as it played such a central role in society and politics during this time, there are a few figures whose actions indicate some level of disregard or unconventional attitudes towards religious norms. However, it's crucial to clarify that their lack of interest doesn't necessarily equate to atheism or agnosticism, but may have been observed in their actions, policies, or perceived prioritization of secular concerns.

1. Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor: Despite being the secular leader of a Christian empire, Frederick II was known for his unusual attitudes towards religion for the period. He was excommunicated twice and was often in conflict with the Papacy. He also demonstrated advanced religious tolerance for his time, especially towards Muslims and Jews in his kingdom. 

2. King John of England: Known for his conflict with the Church, John's relationship with religion was rather complicated. His refusal to accept the Pope's appointment for the Archbishop of Canterbury led to a five-year interdict on all religious services in England and his excommunication. Although he eventually submitted to the Pope's demands, his actions during this period indicate prioritization of political power over religious obligations.

Again, it's worth emphasizing that perceived religious interest or disinterest during these times is more aptly viewed as a degree of compliance with the societal and political norms dictated by the Church, rather than a reflection of personal belief or lack of belief in religious doctrines.
what are the fundamental roles the church played--how would secular, political, warring nobles interact with the church in their goals and lives?

During the Middle Ages, the Church was a dominant institution and held enormous power, not just religiously, but also politically and socially. Its fundamental roles included:

1. Spiritual Guide: The Church was the spiritual backbone of society. It performed religious rites, including baptisms, weddings, and funerals. The Church was responsible for the spiritual well-being of the people and provided moral guidance.

2. Landowner: The Church was a major landowner and had great wealth. It levied taxes (tithes) on its tenants, who were often peasants working in the fields.

3. Educator: The Church was the primary provider of education. It maintained schools, copied out books, and preserved knowledge in the monasteries. Many nobles were educated by priests and monks.

4. Law Enforcement: The Church had its own system of law called 'canon law'. It could exert significant legal penalties, such as excommunication, which would cut a person off from the sacraments and Christian community.

Secular, political, and warring nobles had complex interactions with the Church. Here's how:

1. Legitimacy: Kings and nobles often sought the blessing of the Church to legitimize their rule. The Church's sanction could imbue a ruler's reign with a sense of divine right, reinforcing their authority.

2. Diplomacy: Nobles used their relationships with the Church in political maneuvers and diplomacy. Clergymen often served as scribes, advisors, and diplomats.

3. Conflict: Some kings and nobles fought with the Church over issues like the appointment of bishops (investiture controversy), taxes, and legal jurisdiction. These conflicts could lead to excommunication, placing the nobles in a difficult position.

4. Crusades: The Church initiated the Crusades, religious wars aimed at reclaiming the Holy Land from Muslim rule. Many nobles participated in the Crusades, both to secure salvation and to gain wealth.

5. Alliances: Frequently the Church and nobility would have a symbiotic relationship. Bishops and abbots, chosen from the nobility, ruled vast territories, while nobles relied on Church sanction for their authority. This interdependence blurred secular and ecclesiastical lines.
did any medieval helmets make use of the reflective properties of steel to enable the wearer to look behind him?

Medieval helmets were designed primarily for protection and to provide better field of view for the wearer. While polished steel helmets would indeed reflect light and images, there isn't historical evidence to suggest that medieval helmets were specifically designed with mirrors or polished sections to allow the wearer to see behind themselves.

It's important to note that wearing a helmet and heavy armor reduced a knight's field of vision and mobility, which would make it difficult to take advantage of a reflective surface on a helmet. Furthermore, the nature of combat in the medieval period, which was often chaotic and face-to-face, would likely limit the utility of such a feature.

However, medieval knights and warriors were trained in combat techniques that compensated for the limitations of their helmets and armor. They needed to rely on their senses, their comrades, and a developed spatial awareness to watch for threats outside their field of view. 

In modern times, some motorcycle helmets are designed with built-in rear-view mirror systems. This was not the case with medieval helmets, where the focus was more on providing robust protection against weaponry. The technology and ideology needed to implement such a system in a functional and reliable way just didn't exist in the medieval period.
what do you mean by ideology here?

In the context of the original message, 'ideology' refers to the mindset, thinking, and common beliefs shared by a certain group of people during a certain period. In this case, the people of the medieval period may not have thought of or prioritized the concept of field vision in the same way as we do today.

Today, we understand fields of vision, blind spots, and reflections thanks to science, and we realize their potential applications in safety and warfare, such as in rear-view mirrors on vehicles, periscopes in submarines, or reflective surfaces in tactical warfare. However, during the medieval period, this kind of thinking and perspective was less prevalent or non-existent due to the lack of technology and scientific understanding. 

Instead, helmet design ideology was centered around physical protection from direct assaults. The concept of using mirrors or highly-polished surfaces to broaden visibility might not have occurred to craftspeople or soldiers, or if it did, they may have dismissed it as impractical or unimportant in comparison to other factors, or too difficult to implement with the technology available to them. That’s what is meant by the 'ideology' of the period not supporting such features in helmet design.
